and there are two types of nodes you can set up the first is data nodes data
nodes are the ones that hold your data and respond to the queries that come into elasticsearch you have the ability
to configure the data nodes here with the type of node you want and the number of nodes you want to allocate to that
particular function in addition you can also set up dedicated master nodes now
master nodes are nodes that are the primary responsibility is to help ensure cluster stability in elasticsearch so
they hold some sort of metadata information and really manage the stability of your cluster so you you
have the ability to set those up specifically as well and you can have a different type of node for your master
node versus your data node we highly recommend in any production cluster that you actually have dedicated master nodes
to make sure your cluster is as stable as possible we have options for storage
so you can either use the on instance local store to store your index or if
you if you choose you can use EBS as well to store your index so you can independently sort of scale your
compute and storage resources there's a feature called zone awareness so when
you enable zone awareness in a multi node cluster what the service does is it
automatically distributes the nodes in your cluster into two different availability zones so then if you have a
replication set up your replicas are automatically put on different nodes which are already in different availability zones so you have a higher
level of availability or redundancy built into your service so it's just a matter of clicking that one check box
and that's done for you this UI also lets you set up configurations around

that was the UI and this is a look at all of the api's that we we offer from a

update domain delete domain or describe to me so those fourth actions that you

so let me kind of explain what the domain is real quick this is not an architectural diagram it's just meant to
sort of pictorially represent what domain stands for so an Amazon Elastic
search service domain is essentially it's made up of the the nodes that run
your elastic search service and it has the software that
powers the cluster essentially both our internal software from management as well as the elasticsearch software itself
it contains the the the load balancers the the security and auditing and
monitoring systems all of those are part of what make an actual Amazon elasticsearch domain let's look at each
of these in in more detail so the first one is the nodes under management so we
talked about the two different types of nodes that you can set up in your cluster so the first one is the data node which holds the data response to
queries the second is the master node that manages the cluster stability the service is going to manage all these
nodes for you so it's going to continually monitor these nodes and if node does fail it's going to attempt to
recover it and recover the node nodes where possible so these nodes are completely managed by the service the
next piece is the access to the nodes themselves so we have an ELB in front of
the nodes and the ELB is used to load balanced traffic coming into the cluster there's an entry in there's a DNS entry
in route 53 so you have a single endpoint that you can use to connect to the cluster over HTTP and the service
supports the elasticsearch api so the same api you use today against your with
your applications can be used with the service as well to create and manage indexes or upload
data run search queries all of that stuff so you can use the same elastic search API so super important single
endpoint support for the elastic search api in terms of security I mentioned it
briefly we have integration with AWS Identity and Access Management that's
the way you control access to your cluster and you can do this at multiple levels you can control access that a
domain level or you can do it at an index level or you can even set up specific controls for different
elasticsearch api's that you want to maybe provide access to some users but not to other users and we'll walk
through examples here in a minute and finally we have integration with cloud cloud watching cloud trail from
monitoring and metrics and auditing as I mentioned earlier so that's sort of the high-level picture of what a domain
essentially looks like now that we talked about the domain and and the the
creation process I just want to spend a couple minutes talking about the process of actual scaling and how that works and
also some things to keep in mind when you think about how to configure your domain so let's talk about scaling first
once you set up your cluster and it's active and running you can make changes
to your configuration at any point you can add nodes you can change storage settings you can change your access policies and all of this is done for you
in an online fashion so when you make those changes the service will spin up additional nodes with the right
properties the updated properties it will replicate the data and once that's
done it will spin down the the the old node so all of this is done online there's no disruption to your service
Amazon Elastic search service will take care of all that for you in terms of
other things to keep in mind when when you have to go through your cluster
configuration so one of the things obviously is just how your data structured right so just a quick
background this is probably familiar to a lot of you in the audience that are search people but the the data that is
stored and searched in your domain is essentially stored as an index right the
index is the data that you are using and storing and searching on the index
itself is made up of one or more shards of data so a shard is essentially just a
partition of your large data set and each shard is made up of multiple
documents so the document is the unit of data that you load in to your system and
it's the unit of data that is returned to you as results from your search and analytics queries and finally the
document has you know attributes like via like fields or document IDs and
stuff like that so let's look at a specific example in this example we have
index 1 and index to index one is in green index two is in
blue they both have three shards in this
example and each of the index indexes also has a replica so what that means is
each of the shards end up ends up having a replica so you have a primary set of shards and a replica set of shards so
the primary shards are the ones that are have the bold border on them and then you have the replicas that the primaries
are the ones that would sort of control the region writes in to your index the replicas can be promoted to primary if
needed if the primary goes down for some reason so one thing to keep in mind here
and the reason I brought this up is if you allocate enough nodes to your cluster in this case three then the
service is going to make sure that your primary primary shards and your replica shards are distributed to different
nodes so that you have some level of redundancy so in this example you have
index one primary shard one and instance one and index one replica shard one an
instance two and you can see that sort of done for the other ones as well so the service is gonna do this for you automatically so you want to make sure
that you have enough nodes in your cluster to let the service do this for you and create redundancy if you don't
have enough nodes allocated to your cluster and you have replicas set up one thing to keep in mind an eye out on is
your cluster status it's gonna be yellow so if you see a cluster status yellow you want to kind of check and see if you
have enough notes allocated to your cluster another thing to keep in mind if you're using log stash and you're using
log stash to push data into your Amazon Elastic search service domain lock stash
actually automatically creates a replica of your index so if you don't have enough nodes again it's gonna go yellow
so just keep an eye out on that as well how you set up your shards and how many
shards you set up really has a lot of impact on the configuration of your cluster so you want to really think about that the size of the nodes the
size of the storage options all of those will be impacted by how you how you set up your shards in terms of instance
types and storage options the service provides multiple options for you for instances
we have the choices between t2 sm-3s r3
s and i2 s so each of those work better for different types of workloads t2 is a
great for you know devtest workloads you can you can also use teachers for production especially the larger ones
and you can also use t2 nodes for dedicated masters that we talked about earlier the m3s are general-purpose
instances they provide a balance between you know networking and memory and
compute and they work for a lot of different variety of use cases our 3s
are memory optimized instances they work great for use cases that have complex
query demands if you're running a lot of aggregations for example or you're running a lot of things through Cubana

they're backed by high speed SSDs great for random high i/o with iTunes you can

us a large data set that you want to make searchable or want to analyze that

access to so this is a user policy a user based policy and we're specifying
the user that has control to do what we're allowing them to do the action
element in this policy specifies what we want to let that user do in this case
we're giving them access to be able to execute certain HTTP commands get put posts and then a couple of the
management API s that we have available so we're giving this access are sort of limited control to what they can do and
finally reuse the resource element to specify where they can execute these
types of commands so this is where as I was talking about this can be a domain it can be an index within a domain or it
can be even something more fine-grained than that so this user policy is allowing this user to to do those
actions on a particular index you can change this policy to instead of have
having it as a user policy you can have a wild card for the iron the Amazon resource name and and make it more more
open if you will you can also do IP based access control if the use case
asks for it in this case the changes to the policy as you can see in the
principal element we used the wild card the action and resources are the same but then we have a condition element
where we specify the IP address or the range of ips that we want to let these types of requests come in from so once
you set up this policy any requests coming in from the IP ranges that you specify will be allowed to do those
actions that you give them access to so that's kind of how this security or the securing policies work
